content:
Polycystic kidney: Causes, signs, treatment, prevention

Polycystic kidneys usually appear after the age of 30-40, very rarely in childhood, and are characterized by the appearance of many cysts on both sides of the kidney. The disease can be associated with liver cysts and cardiovascular abnormalities. The disease is dangerous in that it has no specific signs and can only be detected through examination.

What is polycystic kidney (PKD)?
Polycystic kidney disease (PKD) is a genetic disorder in which clusters of cysts develop inside the kidneys, causing the kidneys to gradually increase in size and decline in function over time.
Cysts are non-cancerous, round sacs that contain fluid. Cysts vary in size and they can grow very large. The presence of multiple cysts or large cysts can cause kidney damage.
The disease can also cause cysts to develop in the liver and other parts of the body. Polycystic kidneys can cause serious complications, including high blood pressure and kidney failure.

Causes of polycystic kidneys
The generation and development of kidney cysts depends on two factors: genes and environment. Accordingly, the cause of the disease can come from:
Chemical or medicinal substances, including antioxidants (such as diphenyl-thiazole and nordihydro guaiaretic acid), alloxan and steptozotoxin, lithium chloride and cis-platinium.; Abnormal genes cause polycystic kidney disease, meaning that in most cases, the disease has a genetic component. Sometimes, a genetic mutation occurs spontaneously, so that neither parent has a copy of the mutated gene. (first)
Polycystic kidney disease caused by various genetic defects is divided into two types:
Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD). Signs and symptoms of ADPKD usually develop between the ages of 30 and 40. The disease usually occurs in adults, but children can also develop the disorder. If a parent has the disease, the disease will be passed on to their children. If a parent has ADPKD, each child has a 50% risk of developing the disease. This form accounts for most cases of polycystic kidney disease.; Autosomal recessive polycystic kidney disease (ARPKD): Less common than ADPKD, signs and symptoms usually appear soon after birth. Sometimes, symptoms reappear during childhood or adolescence. Only if both parents have an abnormal gene can inherit this disorder, then each child has a 25% chance of having the disease.
There are three main mechanisms of kidney cyst formation:
Obstruction in the renal tubule lumen; Renal tubular epithelial cell proliferation; Changes in the basement membrane of the kidney tubule

What is the difference between autosomal dominant polycystic kidney and autosomal recessive polycystic kidney?
Based on the above characteristics, we can see the difference between two types of polycystic diseases:
While signs and symptoms of ADPKD usually develop at the age of 30-40, ARPKD appears immediately after birth.; Compared to ADPKD, ARPKD is less common; For ADPKD, if a parent has the disease, the disease will be passed on to their children. As for ARPKD, both parents must have abnormal genes to inherit the disease.; The disease inheritance rate of ADPKD is higher than that of ARPKD

Recognizing signs of the disease
Polycystic kidney disease symptoms may include:
High Blood Pressure; Back or side pain; There is blood in the urine; Feeling of fullness in the stomach; Increased abdominal size due to enlarged kidneys; Headache; Kidney stones; CKD; Urinary tract or kidney infection

Complications of polycystic kidneys
Complications related to polycystic kidney disease include:
High blood pressure: Considered a common complication of polycystic kidney disease. If left untreated, high blood pressure can cause further damage to the kidneys and increase the risk of heart disease and stroke. Hypertension can occur early, occurring at a rate of 13-20% of patients even when there is no kidney failure. (2); Loss of kidney function; It is one of the most serious complications of polycystic kidney disease. Nearly half of people with the disease have kidney failure by age 60. Polycystic kidneys can interfere with the kidney function that keeps waste from building up to harmful levels (uremia). As the disease gets worse, it can lead to end-stage kidney disease. Then continuous kidney dialysis or transplantation is needed to prolong life.; Chronic pain: Pain is a common symptom for people with polycystic kidney disease. Pain often occurs in the hips or back. The pain may also be related to urinary tract infection, kidney stones, or malignancy.; Development of cysts in the liver: The likelihood of developing liver cysts for people with polycystic kidney disease increases with age. While both men and women develop cysts, women more often develop larger cysts. Female hormones and multiple pregnancies may contribute to the development of liver cysts.; Developing an aneurysm in the brain: A balloon-like bulge in a blood vessel in the brain can cause bleeding (hemorrhage) if it ruptures. People with polycystic kidney disease have a high risk of developing aneurysms and conversely, people with a family history of aneurysms have a high risk of developing polycystic kidneys.; Pregnancy complications: Pregnancy is successful for most women with polycystic kidney disease. However, in a few cases, people who were at risk of high blood pressure or impaired kidney function before becoming pregnant may develop a life-threatening disorder called preeclampsia.; Heart valve abnormalities: 1 in 4 adults with polycystic kidney disease has mitral valve prolapse. When this happens, the heart valves no longer close properly, which allows blood to leak back.; Colon problems: Weakness and pockets or pouches in the wall of the colon (diverticulosis) may develop in people with polycystic kidney disease.; Bleeding in the cyst causes gross hematuria: occurs in 15-20% of patients. Gross hematuria often occurs after trauma. Perirenal bleeding rarely occurs; if it occurs, it is usually due to trauma that ruptures the cyst.; Bacterial infection: This is the main reason why people are hospitalized. Bacteria reach the kidneys through the upstream route. If the cyst is infected, the cyst will increase in size and cause pain. On examination, the kidneys are enlarged and painful when pressed; Kidney stones: About 11-34% of patients with polycystic kidneys have kidney stones. Cases of small kidney stones are often difficult to diagnose and easily overlooked.; Kidney cancer: Nearly 50% of kidney cancers occur in patients with this disease (eg, renal cell cancer, a small number of renal papillary cancers). Symptoms are considered when making a diagnosis, including hematuria, low back pain, kidney enlargement, intracystic bleeding.; Kidney failure: This is the most common complication in patients with polycystic kidney disease.; Reduced ability to concentrate urine: Degree depends on cyst volume and number of cysts. Blood sodium levels are often slightly reduced; Anemia: common in patients with severe kidney failure; Hyperuricemia: due to disorders of uric acid reabsorption and excretion of kidney tubules.

Diagnosis of polycystic kidney
To accurately diagnose polycystic kidney disease, your doctor will rely on the following examination factors:
Family history; Ultrasound results showed two large kidneys, with many cysts of different sizes in both the cortex and medulla; There are cysts in the liver; Kidney CT scan; Genetic techniques identify abnormalities at the distal end of the short arm of chromosome 16

Polycystic Kidney (PKD) Treatment
The general principle is to treat symptoms and complications
Kidney infections are treated with appropriate antibiotics; Hypertension is treated with antihypertensive drugs; Nephrectomy if kidney cysts are too large, complications of hematuria, recurrent infection (3); Renal failure, conservative treatment and replacement for end-stage renal failure with dialysis and kidney transplantation.; In cases where the cyst is not too large, peritoneal dialysis can be performed...

Prevent polycystic kidneys
If you have polycystic kidney disease and are considering having children, you should see a genetic doctor for advice and to assess the risk of passing the disease on to your children.; Many people have had the disease for many years without knowing it. Therefore, if you notice the development of some of the signs and symptoms of polycystic kidney disease, see a doctor. If you have a relative such as a parent, sibling or child with polycystic kidney disease, get screened for the disorder.; Keeping your kidneys healthy can help prevent some of the complications of this disease. One of the most important ways you can protect your kidneys is to keep your blood pressure stable.
Some tips to control blood pressure:
Take blood pressure medication as prescribed by your doctor; Maintain a low-salt diet; eat lots of fruits, vegetables and whole grains; Maintain a reasonable weight; If you smoke, quit; Exercise regularly. Maintain at least 30 minutes of moderate physical activity every day.; Limit alcohol use
